title: Andrej Karpathy's Dramatic Reversal: Now Codes 'Mostly in English' with AI Agents
description: In a stunning reversal from his October 2025 skepticism when he said AI agents 'just don't work,' Andrej Karpathy reports that 80% of his coding is now agent-based. He describes it as 'the biggest change to my basic coding workflow in ~2 decades.' Karpathy shifted from 80% manual/20% AI in November 2025 to 80% AI/20% manual by December 2025. Despite the enthusiasm, he warns models still make 'subtle conceptual errors that a slightly sloppy, hasty junior dev might do' - they make wrong assumptions, don't manage confusion, don't seek clarifications, and overcomplicate solutions. He predicts a 2026 'slopacolypse' of low-quality AI-generated code across GitHub and other platforms.
author: Andrej Karpathy / The Decoder

title: Simon Willison's 2026 Predictions: LLM Code Quality Will Become 'Undeniable'
description: Simon Willison shares his predictions for 2026 on the Oxide and Friends podcast. Key predictions: 1 year - 'It will become undeniable that LLMs write good code'; 1 year - 'We're finally going to solve sandboxing'; 1 year - A 'Challenger disaster' for coding agent security; 3 years - The coding agents Jevons paradox will resolve; 3 years - Someone will build a new browser using mainly AI-assisted coding; 6 years - 'Typing code by hand will go the way of punch cards.' Willison bases his code quality prediction on extensive hands-on experience, noting that since Claude Opus 4.5 and GPT-5.2 came out in November/December 2025, 'the amount of code I've written by hand has dropped to a single digit percentage of my overall output.'
author: Simon Willison

title: Amjad Masad's Philosophy: 'Most AI Coding Tools Hide The Code, Replit Doesn't'
description: Replit CEO Amjad Masad emphasizes a key differentiator for Replit's approach: transparency. Unlike many AI coding tools that abstract away or hide the code, Replit keeps code visible and editable. This philosophy aligns with Replit's dramatic growth from $10M to $100M ARR in just 9 months, driven by their AI coding tools. Masad's vision focuses on democratizing software development and making programming accessible to 1 billion developers worldwide, while maintaining the fundamental connection between developers and their code.
author: Amjad Masad

title: DeepSeek R1: Open-Source Reasoning Model Disrupts AI Landscape
description: Chinese AI startup DeepSeek released R1, an open-source reasoning model achieving performance comparable to OpenAI's o1 across math, code, and reasoning tasks. Key features: advanced reasoning capabilities, strong coding benchmarks, cost-efficient development, fully open-source under MIT License. The release has been called 'the game changer' in the open-source community, offering performance competitive with leading proprietary models while being completely free. Multiple distilled versions are available for different use cases, making advanced reasoning capabilities globally accessible.
author: DeepSeek AI

title: Cursor AI Explosive Growth: $100M ARR in 2024, $2.6B Valuation
description: Cursor AI, the AI-powered code editor built on VS Code, experienced explosive growth: revenue jumped from $1M (2023) to $100M (2024) with projected $200M in 2025, reaching a $2.6B valuation by January 2025. Cursor 2.0 introduces multi-agent workflows and deep repo-wide AI integration. Unlike lightweight assistants like GitHub Copilot, Cursor offers comprehensive AI integration throughout the development workflow, integrating with models like Claude 3.5 Sonnet. The tool has sparked extensive community discussion about its autocomplete capabilities and transformation of development workflows.
author: Industry Analysis

title: State of AI Coding 2025: 76% Productivity Increase with More Bugs
description: Greptile's State of AI Coding 2025 report reveals a critical trade-off: developer output increased 76% (lines of code per developer grew from 4,450 to 7,839) as AI coding tools act as a force multiplier. However, JetBrains Developer Ecosystem Survey 2025 reports that 85% of developers regularly use AI tools for coding, with 62% relying on at least one AI tool daily. The landscape is rapidly evolving with a focus on 'agentic tools' - moving beyond simple IDE chatbots to more autonomous coding agents in 2025.
author: Greptile / JetBrains Research

title: Agentic CLI Era: 2025 Marks Shift Beyond Simple Chatbots
description: 2025 marked the start of the 'Agentic Era' in AI coding tools - moving beyond simple IDE chatbots to agentic CLIs with greater autonomy and capability. This shift represents a fundamental change in how developers interact with AI tools, from passive assistants to active agents capable of executing complex multi-step tasks. The evolution includes tools like Synthetic (starting at $20/month) and Cerebras (starting at $50/month), making advanced AI coding capabilities more accessible to developers of all levels.
author: The New Stack

title: ArXiv Research: Guidelines to Prompt LLMs for Code Generation
description: January 2025 saw significant research on AI code generation. Key paper 'Guidelines to Prompt Large Language Models for Code' presents an empirically defined catalog of prompt optimization guidelines for LLM code generation. Another paper 'Guided Code Generation with LLMs: A Multi-Agent Approach' introduces a novel agentic framework using a deliberately structured, fine-grained approach. Additional research on 'Do LLMs Trust the Code They Write?' examines trust issues in LLM-generated code, which often contains errors requiring careful oversight.
author: Multiple Researchers

title: Addy Osmani's LLM Coding Workflow for 2026
description: Addy Osmani shares his comprehensive LLM coding workflow optimized for 2026, documenting best practices for integrating AI assistants into the development process. The guide covers practical patterns for using LLMs effectively, including when to leverage AI tools, how to structure prompts, and workflows that maximize productivity while maintaining code quality. This represents the maturation of AI-assisted development from experimental to mainstream practice.
author: Addy Osmani

title: Replit's Major Security Update: Separating AI from Live Databases
description: Following an incident where AI agents could delete live databases, Replit rolled out a major update to separate AI activity from production databases. CEO Amjad Masad called the incident 'unacceptable' and promised systemic fixes. This highlights a growing concern in the agentic AI era: the need for proper safeguards, sandboxes, and access controls when giving AI agents the ability to modify code and infrastructure. The update reflects the industry's learning curve as AI tools become more powerful and autonomous.
author: Analytics India Magazine
